newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan chip makers cut investment, face profit drop.
newsitem.headline: Japan chip makers cut investment, face profit drop.

text.p: Japanese semiconductor makers, worried by a sharp downturn in memory chip prices, said on Wednesday that they would cut back investments in microchips in the second half of this business year.

The companies, which only last year had reaped record profits thanks to their high-flying microchip business, said the impact of the crash in chip prices would be limited due to surging profits in their information equipment divisions and smaller deficits in consumer electronics.

But analysts say a plunge in parent company profits is inevitable this year due to the companies' heavy reliance on 16-megabit dynamic random access memories (DRAMs), prices of which have nosedived more than 70 percent in the past nine months.
Toshiba Corp said it planned to cut group capital investment for microchips by 10 billion yen ($92.5 million) to 170 billion yen ($1.57 billion) for the year ending March 1997.

Toshiba expects its microchip production for the year to be 10 percent below its original forecast, a company spokesman said. Its forecast for chip sales for the year is now 950 billion yen ($8.79 billion).
NEC Corp, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Hitachi Ltd and Fujitsu Ltd all said they were reviewing their investment programmes.
"It's quite natural for some investments to be carried over into the next year, depending on the market situation," a Hitachi spokesman said.

Prices of 16-megabit DRAMs -- currently the mainstay computer memory chip -- for volume users are being quoted at around 1,200 yen ($11) each, down from around 5,000 yen ($46) at the beginning of this year. Spot prices have been below 1,000 yen ($9) and are still heading downward.

Amid a big supply glut following a worldwide slowdown in personal computer sales, some makers have begun selling 16-megabit DRAMs at between $8.50 and $9, raising concerns about possible dumping suits, an industry source said.

Akira Minamikawa, an analyst at research firm IDC Corp, estimates production costs for a 16-megabit DRAM for small makers at around $12, and for some big South Korean and Japanese makers $8. "The break-even point is approaching for some makers," he said.
Minamikawa said stability in the 16-megabit DRAM market would not come until the October-December quarter of 1997.
Nomura Research Institute expects all microchip makers to make sharp downward revisions in their earnings forecast for the current business year.
It estimates Toshiba's 1996/97 parent current profit at 50 billion yen ($462 million) against the company's own forecast, unveiled on Wednesday, of 121.5 billion yen ($1.12 billion).
NEC's profit is estimated at 85 billion yen ($787 million), Hitachi's at 85 billion yen ($787 million) and Fujitsu's at 65 billion yen ($601 million).
Daiwa Institute of Research expects Toshiba to post parent current profit of 105 billion yen ($972 million) and NEC 90 billion yen ($833 million).
"All the firms will be hit hard by lower chip prices. But results will differ depending on how well their other divisions fare," said Daiwa analyst Mami Indo. ($1=109 yen)
